hobby.message: Urban exploration still your kind of therapy?
Political literature still your guilty pleasure?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Feels off, sure. I mostly keep to the tunnels, working on my own.
Been sticking with my usual hobby—urban exploring. Nothing flashy, just routine lately.
Strange week. Some places locked up tighter than usual since Congress drew new lines.
Fewer friendly faces underground. Makes the hobby quieter, at least.
Yeah, feels off. City’s still twitchy after that blackout mess.
Spent last night in the old maintenance tunnels, part of my usual urban exploring routine.
Funny how my hobby gets harder with every new Congress rule.
People are getting territorial, even below ground.
Not everyone likes outsiders sniffing around lately.
Definitely off. Feels like the floor’s always shifting under us lately.
I poke around old utility tunnels—call it urban exploring, call it a bad habit.
Those tunnels changed after the blackout and Peoples’ Congress got bold.
Used to map wiring and old BCI nodes for fun, now neighbors are wiring things for themselves.
Last time I went down, ran into a group building their own junction.
Suppose it’s still my hobby, just with more company—and more padlocks.
Off? Try unpredictable. Even the pipes downstairs have moods these days.
I spend free nights exploring sealed-off tunnels and old data centers—urban exploring’s my vice.
Last week, I had to dodge a new peoples’ patrol rerouting power by hand.
Found an old network hub, half-gutted, neighbors using it for their own feeds.
Had a drink with them, swapped a few homebrew tips, patched some lines for laughs.
My hobby’s always been a good way to read the city’s pulse.
Now it’s the best place to see who’s really running things.
Everything’s sideways, yeah.
I’ve explored almost every tunnel under this district, even before the BCI days.
Urban exploring’s how I stay sane—mapping networks, tracing old city secrets, making midnight repairs.
Used to just be graffiti and lost workers down there. Now it’s coalition crews rerouting cables, hiding microgrids, trading rumors.
Since the blackout, you hear all the arguments echoing through the pipes—everyone running their own little fiefdom.
Last night I helped splice a line for some locals denied by both the Congress and Council.
We split my homebrew, compared council gaffes, and rewired their sensor feed off the old Halden relay.
Feels like the city’s heart is beating underneath, even if no one topside hears it.
hobby_answer: Yeah, urban exploration. Always preferred tunnels over office lights.
Mostly routine lately. Just checking utilities for dead zones.
Congress keeps everyone topside. Easier to move below now.
Not much to say. If anything's changed, it's quieter down there.
Urban exploration, sure. Beats paperwork.
Lots of new faces underground since the last blackout.
Congress folk can’t monitor what they can’t see.
Sometimes feels like everyone’s scavenging for parts now.
Less Council hassle these days, but more closed doors.
Not usually a social hobby, but lately hard to avoid others.
Little of both. Old tunnels call louder than my inbox these days.
Used to have the damn place to myself, now it's crowded.
After the blackout, folks started using tunnels for power swaps.
Half the time I run into coalition patch teams, not system techs.
Funny—no Council monitors, not even a maintenance bot lately.
You can actually talk to people underground now, instead of hiding.
Strange sense of community took root when everything broke.
Bit of both. Always liked exploring off-limits places more than nine-to-five maintenance.
These days, with the Council lost and the Congress in, everyone thinks the tunnels are fair game.
After Halden’s tricks came out, the whole city started poking into places they ignored for years.
Saw kids running their own lines, maybe even bypassing the old BCI meters.
One night last week we ended up mapping grid changes over homemade vodka.
Feels like the only real order left is down below, patched together by whoever shows up.
Can’t say I miss the drones, but some guys are getting bold—cutting corners, hoarding gear.
Sometimes I think the city’s veins run freer now, even without a pulse.
Mostly urban exploration. Been crawling these tunnels since before the city locked them down.
Used to be just me and the rats—now it’s kids, locals, even old tradesmen down there.
The blackout leveled the field. Folks from every corner scavenging, jury-rigging, arguing over who runs what.
After the data leaks, people stopped trusting the surface. They work it out face to face underground.
Halden’s last little gift shook up the rules—now nobody cares what my score says down there.
I sometimes teach newcomers how to safely trace old circuits, just to stop them frying themselves.
You hear wild stories in the dark—conspiracy, forgiveness, who’s pulling strings next.
Funny, the tunnels feel safer now than most council-run blocks.
Hard to say if it’s the real city, but down below you know who’s got your back.
